references: In order to assess the impact on performance, we devised two approaches: 1) centralized training with or without the key-lock module, and 2) collaborative training within the  Federated Averaging (FedAvg) framework, also with or without the key-lock module. We employed LeNet[35], VGGNet[42], and ResNet[36] as the fundamental networks for training image classification models. A total of forty-four models were trained, utilizing eleven experimental configurations and two distinct training methodologies (centralized and federated), to compare standard networks and those incorporating key-lock modules. The findings are presented in Table I.

To further understand the impact of the key-lock module on model performance, a comparison was conducted between local and global models by inputting a randomly generated key sequence and employing the initial weights of the lock layer on the server at each training round. Given that the proposed FedKL learns a personalized model due to the unique private key, the accuracies of FedKL, as presented in Table I, are averaged over all local clients. Each client’s accuracy is derived from their privately owned key sequence and trained key-lock layer’s parameters. The optimal model is selected from all training rounds, with the average accuracy representing the mean of all clients’ optimal performances. The “Random” row results are obtained by utilizing a randomly generated key sequence and random lock layer weights.

The red solid lines are the results from models with the key-lock module and the blue dashed lines are those from models without the key-lock module.

ResNet-20 ResNet-32 ResNet-18 ResNet-34 VGG-16
CIFAR10 Accuracy
Loss
CIFAR100 Accuracy
Loss
references: In Table II, we illustrate testing accuracies and losses in relation to training epochs for various networks using the CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100 datasets. All models are trained in the centralized mode. The performance disparities between models with and without the key-lock module are relatively minor. In particular, the convergence trends exhibit a strong correlation in numerous instances, such as with ResNet-20 and ResNet-32 trained on CIFAR-100, and ResNet-18 trained on CIFAR-10. As mentioned previously, when higher resolution is employed, improved prediction performance can be observed utilizing the proposed key-lock module. It is logical to infer that this performance enhancement stems from the increased learning capacity derived from the additional two fully-connected layers present in the key-lock module.

references: In Table III, the performance discrepancy is more pronounced for networks with fewer parameters compared to those with a higher number of parameters. The relationship between the lock layer’s parameter count and the model’s total parameter count was quantified, revealing a positive correlation between the performance gap and the weight proportion. As the lock layer parameter proportion decreases, the performance gap narrows. For instance, the smallest network, LeNet, exhibits the highest parameter proportion of 22.43%percent22.4322.43\% and the largest performance gap of 87.00%percent87.0087.00\% on the model with the best average performance of 97.45%percent97.4597.45\%. The parameter proportion of ResNet-20 exceeds that ofResNet-32, yet ResNet-20 outperforms ResNet-32 with a 33.46%percent33.4633.46\% accuracy gap compared to 19.03%percent19.0319.03\% on CIFAR-100. However, the performance gap of ResNet-20 is smaller than that of ResNet-32 (9.28%percent9.289.28\% vs. 13.38%percent13.3813.38\%) on CIFAR-10. The accuracy gaps of ResNet-18 are larger than those of ResNet-34 (2.25%percent2.252.25\% vs. 1.50%percent1.501.50\% on CIFAR-10 and 12.59%percent12.5912.59\% vs. 6.85%percent6.856.85\% on CIFAR-100). VGG-16, with the lowest parameter proportion of 0.097%percent0.0970.097\%, exhibits the smallest performance gaps of 0.32%percent0.320.32\% and 1.46%percent1.461.46\% on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100, respectively. Apart from network architecture, the dataset exerts a non-negligible influence, i.e., CIFAR-100, with a greater number of classes, consistently yields a larger accuracy gap than CIFAR-10, which has fewer classes. This phenomenon is observed in all experiments.

w/ KL ×\times ×\times ×\times ×\times ×\times ×\times
GRNN True
w/o KL
w/ KL
references: In Table IV, qualitative results are presented to demonstrate the comparative performance of defense efficacy against targeted leakage attacks, including DLG and GRNN, with various backbone networks and benchmark datasets. DLG consistently fails when employing ResNet-20 and ResNet-18, and as a result, no data is presented. In the case of utilizing LeNet, the reconstructed image is entirely perturbed once the key-lock module is integrated into the network. When a BN layer or key-lock module was incorporated into LeNet, DLG failed to reconstruct accurate images in all experiments, as DLG directly regresses image pixels by approximating the gradient. In other words, DLG can only reconstruct the true image from a gradient with explicit input data information (refer to Section 3.1 Claim 1: Eqn. 3, Claim 2: Eqn. 13, and Claim 3: Eqn. 22). However, both the BN layer and key-lock module re-normalize feature maps, leading to latent space misalignment and input data information ambiguity within the gradient (see Section 3.1 Claim 4: Eqn. 34 and Proposition 2 Eqn. 37). According to the quantitative results on gradient leakage attacks in Table VI, GRNN is more potent than DLG. Nevertheless, the proposed key-lock module can still effectively prevent true image leakage from gradient-based reconstruction. When employing GRNN on ResNet-18 with an image resolution of 256∗256256256256*256, the reconstructed image is not recognizable for private data identification, even though the reconstructed image contains minimal, albeit visible, information from the true image.

S4.T5.footnotes: black grousetiger beetlecliff dwellingbasset houndsweatshirtradiator grillepigBedlington terrier
references: The GGL first generates an image using the inferred ground-truth label to specify the image category, then fine-tunes the generated image based on the gradient information to make it as similar as possible to the true image. In Table V, the model with the key-lock module generates samples with the same category as the true images. However, it can be observed that the appearances and spatial distributions are significantly different from the true image (see the w/KL column in Table V). The key-lock module effectively prevents GGL from inheriting the semantic and structural information of the true image. For instance, in the first row of the table, the samples generated from the GGL model without the key-lock module display a black grouse with a similar green background color and orientation as the true input image. When the key-lock module is embedded into the model, GGL can still generate images of black grouse using the same label. However, the color distribution and object orientation no longer match the true image. This is also true for the “sweatshirt” examples, where the model with the key-lock module generates four different colors of sweatshirts, none of which match the color (gray) in the true image. In terms of spatial information, significant variance can be observed across all examples when the proposed key-lock module is used. For instance, in the last column of Table V, the generated images of “pig” and “basset hound” exhibit various camera perspectives and distances of view fields. Consequently, it can be concluded that the generated images with the key-lock module are not identifiable from the true image, proving that the true image information is effectively protected from the gradient.

In order to quantitatively evaluate the proposed key-lock module against state-of-the-art gradient leakage methods, we employed four evaluation metrics, including MSE, PSNR, LPIPS (using VGGNet and AlexNet), and SSIM. In Table VI, the results were calculated from the generated images and their corresponding true images. It is consistent that the generated images from the model with the proposed key-lock module have significantly lower similarity compared to those from the model without the key-lock module. This indicates that the key-lock module can effectively defend against gradient leakage attacks. For instance, DLG with LeNet on the MNIST dataset has an MSE score of 49.9749.9749.97, while the one with the key-lock module achieves 140.87140.87140.87, which is 181.91%percent181.91181.91\% higher. When LeNet is embedded with a key-lock module, the MSE score of GRNN on the MNIST dataset increases by 29,460%29percent46029,460\%. As for PSNR, most models without the key-lock module scored between 353535 and 505050. However, when the key-lock module is integrated into the model, the PSNR scores drop to approximately 282828. In terms of LPIPS and SSIM, the former metric focuses on the semantic similarity between two images, while the latter one emphasizes structural similarity. The results from both DLG and GRNN perform significantly worse when the key-lock module is embedded into the model. Furthermore, unlike DLG and GRNN, which generate original true images from the gradient directly, the images generated by GGL are similar to the true images in terms of semantics and structure, as shown in Table V. We found that GGL with the key-lock module can still generate images with rich semantic and structural information. Nevertheless, the key-lock module can reduce the reconstruction capability of GGL by preventing the true image’s information from leaking through the gradient. As a result, the GGL without the key-lock module obtains 0.400.400.40 and 0.390.390.39 on LPIPS using VGGNet and AlexNet, respectively, whereas the results increase to 0.470.470.47 and 0.460.460.46 when the key-lock module is present. Although the SSIM score is only 0.2310.2310.231 for standard GGL, it is reduced to 0.1800.1800.180 by the key-lock module. Based on the quantitative results in Table VI, we can conclude that the proposed key-lock module is capable of effectively protecting private information from being leaked through the gradient.

references: In Table IV, qualitative results are presented to demonstrate the comparative performance of defense efficacy against targeted leakage attacks, including DLG and GRNN, with various backbone networks and benchmark datasets. DLG consistently fails when employing ResNet-20 and ResNet-18, and as a result, no data is presented. In the case of utilizing LeNet, the reconstructed image is entirely perturbed once the key-lock module is integrated into the network. When a BN layer or key-lock module was incorporated into LeNet, DLG failed to reconstruct accurate images in all experiments, as DLG directly regresses image pixels by approximating the gradient. In other words, DLG can only reconstruct the true image from a gradient with explicit input data information (refer to Section 3.1 Claim 1: Eqn. 3, Claim 2: Eqn. 13, and Claim 3: Eqn. 22). However, both the BN layer and key-lock module re-normalize feature maps, leading to latent space misalignment and input data information ambiguity within the gradient (see Section 3.1 Claim 4: Eqn. 34 and Proposition 2 Eqn. 37). According to the quantitative results on gradient leakage attacks in Table VI, GRNN is more potent than DLG. Nevertheless, the proposed key-lock module can still effectively prevent true image leakage from gradient-based reconstruction. When employing GRNN on ResNet-18 with an image resolution of 256∗256256256256*256, the reconstructed image is not recognizable for private data identification, even though the reconstructed image contains minimal, albeit visible, information from the true image.

In order to quantitatively evaluate the proposed key-lock module against state-of-the-art gradient leakage methods, we employed four evaluation metrics, including MSE, PSNR, LPIPS (using VGGNet and AlexNet), and SSIM. In Table VI, the results were calculated from the generated images and their corresponding true images. It is consistent that the generated images from the model with the proposed key-lock module have significantly lower similarity compared to those from the model without the key-lock module. This indicates that the key-lock module can effectively defend against gradient leakage attacks. For instance, DLG with LeNet on the MNIST dataset has an MSE score of 49.9749.9749.97, while the one with the key-lock module achieves 140.87140.87140.87, which is 181.91%percent181.91181.91\% higher. When LeNet is embedded with a key-lock module, the MSE score of GRNN on the MNIST dataset increases by 29,460%29percent46029,460\%. As for PSNR, most models without the key-lock module scored between 353535 and 505050. However, when the key-lock module is integrated into the model, the PSNR scores drop to approximately 282828. In terms of LPIPS and SSIM, the former metric focuses on the semantic similarity between two images, while the latter one emphasizes structural similarity. The results from both DLG and GRNN perform significantly worse when the key-lock module is embedded into the model. Furthermore, unlike DLG and GRNN, which generate original true images from the gradient directly, the images generated by GGL are similar to the true images in terms of semantics and structure, as shown in Table V. We found that GGL with the key-lock module can still generate images with rich semantic and structural information. Nevertheless, the key-lock module can reduce the reconstruction capability of GGL by preventing the true image’s information from leaking through the gradient. As a result, the GGL without the key-lock module obtains 0.400.400.40 and 0.390.390.39 on LPIPS using VGGNet and AlexNet, respectively, whereas the results increase to 0.470.470.47 and 0.460.460.46 when the key-lock module is present. Although the SSIM score is only 0.2310.2310.231 for standard GGL, it is reduced to 0.1800.1800.180 by the key-lock module. Based on the quantitative results in Table VI, we can conclude that the proposed key-lock module is capable of effectively protecting private information from being leaked through the gradient.

references: Our proposed module comprises two components to defend against gradient leakage in gradient-sharing-based training systems, such as FL. We theoretically demonstrated in Section 3.1 that the key-lock module can effectively prevent the inheritance of input data information from being embedded into the gradient of the model. In this section, we experimentally evaluate the influence of the key sequence and lock layer separately for gradient leakage defense. We employ three information-sharing strategies for GRNN and GGL with different backbones trained on various datasets. DLG failed to recover any true images across all scenarios, and the potential reasons have already been discussed in Section 4.3. As a result, no examples from DLG are presented in Table VII. Factors such as network complexity and image resolution are considered. The private key can be used to calculate the gradient of the lock layer, but the reverse is not possible (see Eqns. 35 & 36). Consequently, the gradient in Eqn. 37 can be inferred theoretically. When the image resolution is fixed at 32∗32323232*32, GRNN can successfully perform gradient leakage attacks by providing a private key only, while it fails to recover any meaningful visual content by providing the parameters of the key-lock module only. The image quality can be further improved by providing both the private key sequence and the parameters of the key-lock module. A similar case is observed when ResNet-18 with a resolution of 256∗256256256256*256 is used. We can conclude that although both the key and the parameters of the key-lock module contribute to gradient protection, the private key information plays a more significant role in defending against gradient leakage attacks.
